text: Unlike other chapters concerning Yakov, this final one is relatively straightforward. The parodies and stylistic flourishes are diminished, at least until its concluding section. It is also markedly shorter.
A word (verb, adjective) used repeatedly with connection to Yakov. See R163/E25, R189/70, R197/E86, R274/E219, and R277/E223.

A polymorphic character who occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dog keeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article, Sokolov himself stated: "the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is 'sophisticated', because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il'ia) 'The Hunter's Tale', where he is the youth living in his mother's house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); 'The Hunter's Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition', where he is Iakov Il'ich Palamakhterov, 'the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,' and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; 'Pictures from an Exhibition' (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge.
Patronymic: son of Ilya. Yakov may, indeed, be Ilya's son.

Ostanin (43) suggests interpretинг his last name as a variation of "Palamakherov" (from the verb palit', to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are, "So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!" ("Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки") (R280/E230). Ostanin also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.

highlighted: человек заурядного роста, обычного возраста и без труда забывающегося лица
text: A possible allusion to Gogol's description of Chichikov, the hero of his famous *Dead Souls*: "В бричке сидел господин, не красавец, но и не дурной наружности, ни слишком толст, ни слишком тонок; нельзя сказать, чтобы стар, однако ж и не так чтобы слишком молод." Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/78/p.2/index.html).

text:
Sokolov himself spent the period between May 1972 and November 1973 at the hunting estate located near Bezborodovo in the Kalinin oblast (today Tver') by the Volga river. These months constitute one of the most significant periods in the writer’s life. In Bezborodovo, Sokolov not only wrote his first novel, but collected material that would become fundamental for his later work. Bezborodovo and the adjacent villages along the Volga river constitute a highly mythopoeic place in Sokolov’s mental map. These landscapes did not disappear from the writer’s memories even after emigrating: when later on, in Vienna, at the Kunsthistorisches Museum Sokolov found himself admiring some paintings by Bruegel the Elder, he was surprised to find such strong similarities with the hunting estate where he had lived two years earlier.
In 1982, Sokolov devoted a section of his essay Na sokrovennykh skryzhaliakh (On Secret Tablets) to Bezborodovo: "Strange, mysterious, and tragic events occurred in that indigent place, where, besides me, Chaikovskii, Prishvin, and Rilke with his Russian translator Drozhzhin used to find peace and freedom, but where a man’s soul is not worth much more than a pair of boots. There the Volga, otherwise known as the Lethe, flows until it runs into the Turkish sea of oblivion. Enjoying tea made with its water and learning what is going on around its banks, you become forever privy to the inexplicable and unfamiliar—in the river itself and in the fates of those doomed to be with her."
In Bezborodovo Sasha Sokolov had time to observe, listen, create, and write. *Between Dog and Wolf*, which recovers many images and voices ‘recorded’ by Sokolov during his period spent on the Volga and left to settle over time, would appear only later on. See also Napolitano's monograph (2022), in particular chapter 1.
Ironic: usually what is described as "small" is also said to be "but comfortable". Here it is "small, but uncomfortable".
prefix:
а. Яков Ильич жил за 
Волгой, в
suffix: казенной избе у края рамени, на

text: The expression "kazyonnaia izba" (the 'treasury' izba) is attested since 1578. It indicates a place where local inhabitants went to pay taxes under the Tsars' rule. The adjective "kazyonny" however could be here intended as both meaning "governmental, belonging to the State," or as "ordinary, commonplace."
Dialectical: coniferous forest.
prefix: о неуютной казенной избе у края

text: A variation on Krylobyl's name.

Ostanin (43) suggests interpretинг his last name as a variation of "Palamakherov" (from the verb palit', to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are, "So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!" ("Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки") (R280/E230). Ostanin also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.
Various characters sew in the novel. In Yakov's eighth poem, an oriole "resews evening into night" (R172/E39). Sewing is also mentioned in Note XVI (R200/E92). Yakov sews slippers (R274/E219).
Traditional Tatar footwear. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5e/%D0%98%D1%87%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B8.jpg) Shoe motif.
According to Ostanin, "tools, including those for hunting and fishing, nets and tackle" (114). Sokolov corrects: "hunting footwear" ("Bol'shoe pis'mo" 138). Shoe motif.
suffix:
, смотрел на воду, пил, 
ходил н

text: A variation of the set expression "v vodu smotret'": to predict the future.
Jacket potato or baked potato. Chapter 5 begins with Yakov's *Self-Portrait in Uniform* (R183/E61).
suffix: и, желая разобраться в себе, пы

text: Throughout the novel, Yakov's identity has come into question. In chapter 5, he is associated with the idea of camouflage. He may or may not be Ilya's son with Orina. Furthermore, he may be the author of every part of the novel. In short, much like Yakov himself, the reader struggles to sort out his character as well. These questions that blend identity, time, and personhood are typical of Sokolov's three novels. Larissa Rudova writes of *Palisandriia*'s hero: "Since no true historical experience is possible, Palisandr is bogged down with the existential question about who he is" ("Paradigms" 68).
Dated: related to fishing.
Similar phrasing is used in Note XXIV (R233/E144–145).
prefix: о, во фляге выходило горючее, и

text: The narrator alludes to Ilya, who drinks constantly and "comes to a bad end," a euphemistic description of the hunters' murder.

text: A paraphrase of a line from the "[Bela](https://ilibrary.ru/text/12/p.2/index.html)" chapter of Mikhail Lermontov's *A Hero of Our Time* (1841). Yakov is reminded of Lermontov's narrator's words as he looks at his kettle. Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/12/p.2/index.html) and a translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/913/pg913-images.html).

The [Caucasus](https://www.google.com/maps?q=caucasus&um=1&ie=UTF-8&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjz57qU4_v7AhXQnHIEHfG1CGwQ_AUoAnoECAEQBA). The region between the Black Sea and Caspian Sea. Includes such countries as Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, and parts of Russia and the Caucasus Mountains.

text: For instance, the various Caucasian texts alluded to in chapter 12 (R241/E161): Mikhail Lermontov's 1840 poem "The Novice" [Russian](https://ilibrary.ru/text/991/p.1/index.html)/[Russian](https://web.archive.org/web/20140302072320/http://www.friends-partners.org/friends/literature/19century/lermontov/lermontov38.html), Alexander Pushkin's 1822 poem "The Prisoner of the Caucasus" ([Russian](https://ilibrary.ru/text/441/p.1/index.html)/[English](https://aleksandr-pushkin.su/poemy/kavkazskij-plennik/?lang=en)), Lev Tolstoy's later story of the same name (1872) ([Russian](https://ilibrary.ru/text/1846/p.1/index.html)/[English](https://www.marxists.org/archive/tolstoy/1872/captive-in-the-caucasus.html)), and Tolstoy's "Cossacks" ([Russian](http://az.lib.ru/t/tolstoj_lew_nikolaewich/text_0160.shtml)/[English](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/4761/4761-h/4761-h.htm)).

A Russian typical fur hat. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5c/Ushanka_of_Soldier_of_Soviet_Army-5.jpg). Clothing motif.

A polymorphic character who occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dog keeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article, Sokolov himself stated: "the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is 'sophisticated', because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il'ia) 'The Hunter's Tale', where he is the youth living in his mother's house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); 'The Hunter's Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition', where he is Iakov Il'ich Palamakhterov, 'the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,' and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; 'Pictures from an Exhibition' (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge.
Patronymic: son of Ilya. Yakov may, indeed, be Ilya's son.
Dated: wagon train.

A polymorphic character who occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dog keeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article, Sokolov himself stated: "the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is 'sophisticated', because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il'ia) 'The Hunter's Tale', where he is the youth living in his mother's house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); 'The Hunter's Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition', where he is Iakov Il'ich Palamakhterov, 'the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,' and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; 'Pictures from an Exhibition' (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge.
Patronymic: son of Ilya. Yakov may, indeed, be Ilya's son.
This adjective is usually used in the set expression "the Lord works in mysterious ways."

Ostanin (43) suggests interpreting his last name as a variation of "Palamakherov" (from the verb palit', to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are, "So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!" ("Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки") (R280/E230). Ostanin also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.

highlighted:

в его монологе
text: Again, Ilya has adopted someone else's—Ilya's—voice in this section. A possible allusion to Anton Chekhov's *Uncle Vanya*:  "A human being should be entirely beautiful: the face, the clothes, the mind, the thoughts. Your step-mother is, of course, beautiful to look at, but don't you see? She does nothing but sleep and eat and walk and bewitch us, and that is all." Read the original Russian [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/972/p.1/index.html) and English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1756/1756-h/1756-h.htm).

text: Yakov, as other characters do, feels a pull toward death and oblivion. If all the events in the novel are repeating and cycling, then his desire that "nothing repeats" again speaks directly to the structure of the work.
